Award.AwardTitle: Transition Metal Clusters as Single-Molecule Magnets
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor George Christou of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Florida is seeking new molecular compounds that can function as nanoscale magnetic materials with properties relevant to new 21st century technologies such as quantum computers and spintronics. Molecular chemistry brings advantages such as solubility and crystallinity to this goal. It also provides methods for optimizing molecules for particular studies, such as characterizing the quantum physics properties important to these potential applications. The project's scope is broad spanning chemistry and physics. The project also provides new knowledge at the nanoscale that is not often available from traditional magnetic nanoparticles. The multi-disciplinary nature of the research also provides broad, high-level education and training for students, including underrepresented minorities. In addition, a number of outreach, education and international activities are carried out, including state and international conference organization and an annual Chemistry Day in the local community targeted at K-12 students.

This research consists of two main objectives. The first one is to synthesize covalently-linked aggregates of two or more single-molecule magnets (SMMs) linked by dioximate or dicarboxylate bridges and to study their magnetic and quantum physics properties. Weak interactions between the SMMs leads to quantum superposition/entanglement states. These nebulous and fragile effects are detected and studied with techniques such as high-frequency electron paramagnetic (HFEPR) spectroscopy in the solid state. Extension of the HFEPR studies to frozen solutions is crucial to determine if structures and quantum effects remain unchanged on dissolution, providing a second phase for their study. The second objective is the preparation of molecules with a Mnx/O (x = 8-12) cage-like structures containing a heterometal M' of a different type (M' = Ca, La, Ln, Bi, Pb, etc.) at their center. The goal is to mimic in molecular compounds the repeating unit of certain mixed-metal oxides with the perovskite structure, particularly BiMnO3 and LnMnO3 (Ln = lanthanide) that are multiferroics, and thus to prepare molecules that function as 'molecular multiferroics', exhibiting both SMM and switchable electric polarization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project involved two main thrusts in the general area of magnetic molecules, which are molecules possessing unpaired electrons. In the first, the objective was to synthesize a sub-group of magnetic molecules called single-molecule magnets (SMMs) that can function as ultra-small magnetic nanoparticles, and join two or more of them together using covalent organic linkers into still-molecular oligomers. It is known that magnetic molecules will interact with each other when linked this way and that this interaction causes interesting quantum properties to be exhibited, such as exchange-biased quantum tunneling of the magnetization vector, quantum superposition states, and quantum entanglement. These properties form the basis of new 21st century technologies such as quantum computing, but they are nebulous and fragile properties difficult to control; however, our use of molecular Mn3 SMMs with a triangular structure provided us an excellent platform for their detection and study with techniques such as micro-SQUID magnetometry at millikelvin temperatures and high-frequency electron paramagnetic (HFEPR) spectroscopy. In addition, choice of the shape (linear vs V-shaped) and length of the organic linkers allowed the number of Mn3 SMMs linked together and the strength of the interaction between them to be controlled. In the second thrust, the target has been the preparation of molecules with Mnx/O (x = 8-12) cage-like structures and a different metal M′ (M′ = Ca, La, Ln, Bi, Pb, etc.) at their center. The objective was to mimic in molecular compounds the repeating unit of certain 3-D mixed-metal oxides with the perovskite structure, particularly BiMnO3 and LnMnO3, which are fascinating materials with both important magnetic and electric properties, and to characterize their magnetic and electric properties and how these relate to the bulk metal oxides. Success was achieved in preparing molecules that represent the repeating unit of CeMnO3 in molecular form, and remarkably these molecules exhibited the same ordering of their unpaired electrons (so-called “C-type antiferromagnetism”) common within magnetic perovskite solids where it is usually attributed to long-range 3D effects. The synthesis of this compound and its remarkable magnetic properties represented a breakthrough proof-of-feasibility that has opened up a new area of molecules as molecular representations of ultra-small nanoparticles of these important bulk metal oxides.   

The P.I. and his group also carried out a range of broader impact activities throughout the funding period, spanning education, domestic and international conference organization, and outreach: (a) The P.I.’s group supported the planning and execution of the chemistry demonstrations and other activities in the annual Chemistry Day at the Mall in Gainesville, FL, targeted at K-12 students, their teachers and parents, and the local community and media. These events are directed at increasing public awareness of the impact of chemistry in our daily lives, and to foster greater awareness and interactions between the chemistry department and the local community. The event was always a great community and media success; (b) The P.I. had an undergraduate in his group at all times getting research experience; (c) The P.I.’s group assisted synthetic chemists at overseas institutions in the characterization of their materials via magnetic studies using the SQUID magnetometer; (d) The P.I. organized every year the Showcase Symposium, which he founded in 2012, at the annual meeting of the ACS Florida Section, designed to showcase senior scientists and educators in the state of Florida, and foster increased interactions among Florida colleges and universities; (e) The P.I. also organized the annual Florida Inorganic and Materials Symposium (FIMS) student meetings of Florida higher education institutions spanning fourteen undergraduate and PhD granting universities, including the historically black Florida A&M University; only undergraduate and graduate students may give oral presentations, one per group; (f) The P.I. co-organized two international workshops, the Current Trends in Molecular and Nanoscale Magnetism (CTMNM) meeting (Sparta, Greece, June 2018), a specialized magnetism workshop spanning chemistry and physics, and the broad North America-Greece-Cyprus Workshop on Paramagnetic Materials (NAGC) (Paphos, Cyprus, 2017 and Rhodes, Greece, May 2019) spanning chemistry, physics and materials science. Both the CTMNM and NAGC workshops included many oral presentations from students and postdoctorals, including students from the P.I.’s group. (g) The P.I. founded the Molecular Magnetism in North America (MAGNA) workshop to help bring together the North American research community in this area on an annual basis to stimulate new research collaborations, educational thrusts, and funding initiatives, and to provide the next generation of junior scientists a forum for their development.
